div.p: Imprinted at London in Powles Churchyarde by Richarde Iugge printer to the Quenes Maiestie.
Cum priuilegiō Regiae Maiestatis.
¶ An History briefly contayninge that whiche hath happened sens the departure of the house of Guise, the Constable, and other from the Court being at S. Germanis, vntill this present.
div.q: ISAYE THE XLV. ¶ Cursed be he that resisteth his maker.

div.head: ¶ An Historye briefelye contayninge that whiche hath happened sens the departure of the house of Guise the Constable, and others from the Court being at S. Germanis vntill this present.

epigraph.q: ¶ Cursed be he that resisteth his maker.

div.p:
THe Queene hauing according to her accustomed goodnes) accepte the charge of the gouernemente of thys Realme, offered vnto her by the Estates, and by the consent & motion of the king of Nauarre, and my Lordes his brethren, & Cousins, the Princes of the blood: doing therin the office of a mother, aswell towardes the Kynge, as towardes her subiectes, hath well declared
that she had nothing more to harte, then to geue order touchinge the troubles and tumultes risinge by meanes of religion: Not hauing ceassed to find out through her wisdome and carefulnes, all the remedies and meanes, that haue bene thought diuisable to this effect. After that she hadde knowen by examples past, that the rigor of lawes, and streict execuiton coulde doe no good, and contrariwise that thashes of one burned did reise by an infinit number of others, of the same opinion, and like constancye, and that also it was not sittynge to the age nor disposicion of a yong Prince, to begynne his reigne by shedinge of blood, and hauing sithens likewise followed and executed the determinacions agreed vppon, in the late time of kinge Fraunces the laste at Fountainebarn whiche was to assemble all those which would come to make anye demonstration touching the maner of religion, and to deuyse if that by anye meane of conference, the saide troubles and sturres might be brought to an end: and hauing lastely left nothing vndone
whyche myghte serue to the common quiet and tranquilitye, she hath bene constrained in thende (to appease these vprores) to take the remedy of the Edict made in Ianuary last, in loking for the end of the generall counsaile, to satisfy by this meanes (at the lestwise in some partye) the very earnest complainct and request of thestates of this Realme.

And albeit by meanes of the son, the Quene had geuen all men great occasion of contentacion, hauing folowed therin thaduise of the moste notable and piked companye out of all the Courtes of Parlamente of this Realme, and hauing therin obserued all the solemnite, that coulde be wyshed, yet neuertheles some (of whom we will speake herafter) perhaps not wel pleased for some other cause (as indede it is harde to please euery man) they determined to hinder the executiō of thedict, by al the meanes they coulde, together with this determinacion of the Queene, hauinge taken weapon in hande, came to be about the kinges person and the Quenes, aucthorizing them selues with their Princes, and abusing
the kinge of Nauarres aucthority, against my Lord the Prince of Condee, who desirous on the other side to maintayne that whiche was graunted to thestates, did also arme himselfe to stay their rage and fury, and to resist the same to his power. And forasmuch as many may be ignoraunt of the particuler dyscourse of this tumulte, and speciallye the causes and reasons that maye haue moued and may moue thone partye and thother, I thought I shuld do a thing no lesse acceptable then profitable, to set them forth, & giue them trulye tunderstande to all men and specially to them which are minded to serue and feight on thone side or thother, to the ende that the playne trueth of the thynge knowne to all menne, euerye one maye the better iudge whiche side of the twoo, hath moost reason with them, and is best grounded for the cause of their entery into armes.

These shall be to let them vnderstand, that the Quene being readye to assemble a good & notable number of presidentes and counsellors, out of all the parlamentes of thys
Realme, to consult vppon some necessary remedy, for ye ceasing of the troubles, and answering the request of the states, desiring very instantly to haue Churches appointed them. The house of Gwyse beganne to murmure and saye, that they sawe wel, that the matter wolde come to and Interim, and by thys meanes abolishe the religion of the Church of Roome, and that this was not the meanes to slake and lay downe the troubles, which (they saide) proceaded not but of the sufferaunce of those who gaue so easy entry to the Heretiques, to plant and sow heresyes, and throughe the neglygence and bearinge of the Maiestrates and Ministers of Iustice, and so proceadinge further, beganne by coulorable termes, to blayme the Queene for her ouermuch softnes, and openly to accuse the kynge of Nauarre (who truelye hathe bene one that hath asmuche holpen to plant, and set forwarde the Religyon in thys Realme, as presently vnder his authoritye some do assaye to reuoque and supplant the same) & my lordes hys brethren, and other Prynces
of the blood, in blaminge their maner of gouernment, and castinge vpon theym all the faulte, euen as thoughe the troubles had not bene stirred before this kinges raigne addyng further, that if the wayes to roote out heresyes, holden by the Kynges heretofore, had bene followed, that they should not haue fallen into these inconueniences, and that thonely remedy had bene to reproue theim, & to obserue Thedict, made in Iuly last before to driue awaye all the Mynysters, and not to permitte any more assemblyes, and that it should haue bene easy by this meanes, to cause tholde religion, to be kept vpright, & that therefore seing al thinges proceade contrary to their mindes, they hadde rather depart from the Court (as indede they did,) about thend of Nouember last past giuing men clerely tunderstand their discontentacion, which within few dayes after increased sumwhat more; by meanes of the processe, made against ye Duke de Nemours, stirred vppe by theym, to go aboute the taking and conueyinge awaye with him by force, the Duke of Orleauns,
and so hauyng him at the deuocion to make him the heade of their enterprise wherof we wil here no further intreat.

And now that the Duke of Guise and his brethren were departed the Courte, they began euen furthwith to practise by all the meanes they coulde, to bringe their pourposes to passe, whiche was to retourne with greater fauour & aucthoriti, then (as they thought) they departed thens.

And takynge the title of religion, they assay, to win and draw to their partye (by thelp of the Popes Legat (Madame de Guise vncle) the King of Nauarre & the Constable. Which thei in thēd easely brought to passe, that is to say, the kyng of Nauarre, by inducinge of him into a vayne hope, to be agayne inuested in hys kyngdom of Nauarre. And that the Pope should recompence the kynge of spaine, so that the sayde kynge of Nauarre woulde mayntayne the Church of Rome, and the said Constable, by the meanes of a matter in compremise touching a controuersy betwene them concerninge the landes of the Lordeship of Dampmartyn
to whom also it was proponed, that if this religion (which is called new) toke place, that the same shuld be a planke to steppe ryght vpon, to the request made by thestates, which was to thende that the sayde house of Guise, he himselfe, and the Marshal S. Andre, and others should be called vpon to giue accoumpt of the exceading large giftes receyued by thē of the treasure of ye Realme therby to helpe to discharge the king of his deptes, which matter also serued to pourpose to bring in to them the Mareshall S. Andre, beinge otherwyse drawē therto by the Cardynal of Turnon, whiche also was a pertye, besydes other matters whyche the tyme may discouer.

Hauing thus deuised their plat, thei ceassed not to sollicite the Kinge of Nauarre, to declare himselfe to bee for the pope. The king of Nauarre, began euen furthwith openlye and before all the worlde, to shewe that he woulde mainteine the Romyshe religion, he droue away from about him the Ministers, he goth to Masse to the mooste notable Churches of Paris, goeth about to constraine by
all meanes the Quene of Nauarre, and my Lord the Prince, his sonne, to go thither also: and to be short, there is nothinge that he doeth not.

And albeit that he was preuye at the making of the Edict set furth in Ianuarie, and likewise allowed the same, notwithstandinge he was so sollicited & practised, that the matter beynge moued to be spoken of in the Court of parlament, for the intimating therof he being arriued at Paris for thys purpose, dyd in dede nothinge in it at al. And on thother side the bishop of Auxerre his housholde seruaunt, did so muche vnder hande by procuringe of fautors and secret handlynge, by giuinge secret intelligence to the presidentes, and some of the counsellors of the sayde parlament, of the determinations of the D. of Guise, that Thedict by this meanes was staied, from being verifyed. The prouost of the marchauntes at Paris, on thother side stirred by the same meane, together with certain factions merchauntes, dyd so muche by oppositions, wise, and goynge to and fro one in an others necke, that the second time he
staied the said verification (wherunto the numbre of Church men hopes much) whiche made the third parte of the sayde Court of parlamente & was framed in a maner altogether for the Popes appetit so as in thend the Edict could not be suffered to be verified, but by meanes of assistance geuen by my Lorde the Prince of la Roche Sur yon, sent by the king to this ende to the sayde Court, whose presence & reuerence made the sayde oueropen partialitie, beinge in the sayde Court ashamed, whiche then was disseuered, and banished away to the greate confusion of thefactions partye.

In this meane tyme the Duke of Guise ceased not on thother part to vse his practise in Sauarne a towne of almaine where he was, and pressed men of warre, to haue them ready at nede. Seinge perfectlye that this enterprise could not be brought to passe, without force of Armes, so as the said house of Guise, the Constable, and the Marshall S. Andre, perceyuing this Edict to be thus verifyed, to their great griefe, and displeasure, he determined further besides
their first intentes and purposes, to come strong & armed into the towne of Paris, and from thence to the kinges Court, to thintent they beinge first seased of the towne, together with the persons of the king and Queene, they might then more easely execute their enterprise: and the Duke of Guise to geue a more honest color of his returne, procured that he shuld be sent so by the kinge of Nauarre, and that withoute the Quenes knowledge. The said Constable at the same tyme willinge to take occasion, to departe frome the Court discontented, hauing within a fewe dayes gone twise oute of the Court, at the last tyme entred in to so earnest a standing in words with the Quene, that she bare good witnes of the small respect he had to the honor and reuerence he bare towardes her. And as for the marshall S. Andre not satisfyinge himselfe with tharrogante refusuall made by him to go to his gouernment and charg, vpon the trust he reposed in his faction, (by whom he perceiued himself upholden) he stode in termes before the counsaile with the sayde Lady,
with such countenaunce and words as declared small obedience.

Hauinge then brought foorth their enterprises thus farre forward, the Duke of Guise retourning from his iourney into Almain, to geue knowledge firste of all others, the hostile enemite that he bare towardes religion, which he minded to persecute, and all them also which woulde fauour the same, toke his way of a set pourpose throughe a Towne of Champaigne called Wassy, beinge informed that there was in the same a reformed Church: and beyng there arriued and accompanied with certeine menne of warre he made there such and so cruel a bochery & slaughter of poore people the kinges subiectes, that there were no fewer thē foure score personnes killed, and as many or more hurt, amonges whom ther were women and litle children altogether assembled withoute any weapons, to heare the Sermon, and to pray vnto god after their accustomed fashion.

The feare hereof being brought to paris, all men of one syde and other were greatly troubled, loking verely,
that this was not but the beginnynge of a greate myschiefe, and streight waies the rumor was spred abroade euery where, that the D. of Guise came in armes with a greate company, with determination vtterly to supppresse all the reformed Churches. The which also for their partes, in consideracion, that it seemed the kinges Edict could not defend them against the violence & fury of their enemies, stode vpon their gard, hauing first sent to the Quene certain personages of al sorts, to require Iustyce at her handes, for the murthers commytted at the sayds place of Wassy. The Quene beyng then come to Monceaux wyth the king in a maner alone. The king of Nauarre, the Mareshall S. Andre, the Mareshall Brisac, and others being at Paris, whither sone after came ye Constable: Who comming from his house thyther, wyth the hoole heires and of hys frendes and seruauntes, met (nere vnto S. Denis) the king and the Quene, going to Monceaux, and withoute doing of any duty to them, hastenyng to winne Paris, passed by theym as
though he had costed by a company of vnknowen people, notwythstandyng that Le Seigneur de Sansac, warned hym to stay, tellinge hym, Sir yonder is the king, the Constable answering that he knew it well inough.

Aboute this tyme, my Lorde the Prynce of Condee hauynge taken leue of the kynge and the Quene to go home to his house and being arriued at Paris, desyring to prouyde for the daungers whiche threatned the towne, departed thence, vppon the Quens sending for him, to mete with the king and her at Monceaux where he toulde them that whyche he feared, and that to auoid the troubles it should be well done, that the sayde D. of Guise (who was reported to come with greate power and stronge hande, in contraryinge the kinges ordinances) at the lest might not passe through the towne of Paris, which aduice was well allowed by the Quene and the kinge of Nauarre, and accordinge to the same, the sayde Lady wrote very expressely to the Duke of Guise being then at hys house of Nantueil, prayinge
him to come and mete the kynge at Monceaur, declaring vnto him, the desire she had to se him, and to feast him in her house. The sayd Duke of Guise sent worde vnto her, for aunswere, that he could not come to her for that he was busyed and letted in banquetting of his frendes whiche wer come to se hym. After warde the Quene hauinge againe written to the sayde Duke of Guise letters of the sentens, receyued no aunswers at all from him. But after he had interteined his frends, (in folowing the determinacion of thenterprise) tooke his waye to Paris, thoughe it were further of from him, then to goo meete the Kynge and the Quene at Monceaux, whyche was nerer hande.

Thus the Duke of Guise accompanied with the Constable, the D. Dammale, the Marshal S. Andre, & others of Coūsail in their enterprise came into Paris by S. Denys gate, (though his right way were to haue entred by S. Martyns gate,) makynge hys entrey in open armure, whiche was the state he kept continuallye, since hys dayes woorke at
Wassy. And there assisted him likewise at this entry the prouost of the Marchauntes, and thre of them Escheuing against al custome, who (as he is a lighte and a factious person) went to receyue hym, wyth a verye greate company and with great acclamations made by people suborned therunto, as if the king himself were entred in person, in so muche as they cried alowd, God saue the Duke of Guise without that, (notwithstanstanding the said Duke or others of his company made any demonstration that the same did at all mislike them: And immediatlye after ye said D. of Guise was thus arriued & receyued into the towne of Paris, the said Constable, the Marshal S. Andre & the Marshall Brisac, began to bold daily a priuate counsail amōgs theym selues, forbearinge to call to theim the Prince of Condee, beinge there present with theim. Whyle these things were in hand, the king, the Quene, and the king of Nauarre remayninge as yet at Monceaux. The Quene (hauing had aduertisemente from three places, that is to saye, from Portugall, Spayne, and
Sauoy, of enterprise of the house of Guise, minding to sease then of the persons of the king and her, & of all those things which she findeth true at this day: she determined to hasten her departure, & to retire her self to some place of safety. And hauing imparted her letters to the king of Nauarre, they departed from the saide place & came to Melun, pourposyng to haue attained to Orleans: and sodenly there arriued the prouost of marchantes suborned for the nones, criyng vpon the Quene, yt if she retired from Paris al was lost, saiyng yt ye Prince of Condee was ther with a great nūber of men, protesting, that al ye euil which might happen shuld be turned vpon her, & not vpon him, with manye other lyke foolishe and rashe deuises set forth then by him: So as though the said Lady be a ladye of singuler vertue and constancye, beinge neuerthelesse put in feare of all sides, agreed to goo to Fontaniebleau: And the prouost of Marchantes hauinge thus farre wonne her, beganne to tell her, that the Cytyzens of the Towne
of Paris were vnarmed, and that the Prince of Condee was then armed, that the said Citizens were in great daunger, and he dyd so much with her that he obtained, that their armure shuld be restored vnto them, whyche in deede were before taken from them, & put within the towne house, to preuent troubles & sturres which were before in the said town, and beganne again after they were restored. And furthermore the meanes of the said prouost of Marchauntes was non other, but to strengthē the Duke of Guise alwayes in the towne, knowing wel that he would retire himselfe thither beynge ones feased of the persons of the king and Quene. The Prince of Condee was in thys meane tyme wythin the towne of Paris, wyth some whyche then were about hym, beyng kepte there at the request of diuerse of the reformed religion, who feared much the armed vyolence of the Duke of Guise and in deede hys presence dyd stay much, that there was no trouble and that the vulgar people, whiche alreadye began to be puffed vp, wyth a vaine hope, vppon the D. of
Guises comming, durst not execute or begin any folish enterprise. The towne hauing bene durynge hys abode there in great quiet and reste, they that came thither euil disposed, and durst not as then to vtter themselues, as in dede they did afterwardes, when they saw they were alone and no more kepte backe with thys bridle & seing that by meanes thereof they could not execute their purpose neither at Paris nor elswhere, they did so much in thend, that they caused the king of Nauarre to come vnto them, vsing still the meanes of their prouost of Marchantes, which went to call vpon him, that his presence was nedeful at Paris for the daunger of vprores.

The kinge of Nauarre beinge then arriued, the Duke of Guise and all his traine were verye glad, and beginninge to kepe their counsaill as they did before, and causing the kinges ministers, presidentes, counsellors & officers of the towne to come vnto them, they made them tunderstande that thys was in dede the kinges counsail, as kept by the chief officers of the Realme, and so they made their consultacions together
without calling the saide Lorde the Prynce of Condee vnto theym, no more then they did before. Al which consultacions were greatlye suspected, speciallye to men of honour and qualitie, who coulde not be perswaded, that it was nedefull or lawful to kepe the same thus apart, and seuered from the counsail remaininge about the king and the Quene, and namely seing the said Lorde Prince was present there, and yet nothinge was com •••• icated vnto him. Al those which had neuer so litle know ledge of the affaires iudged verily, that this was nothing elles, but a continuaunte of a practyse, whiche was framed a great while before, & that which didde the more confirme this opinion, was the discontentacion which was well knowne to be in theym of the house of Guyse the Constable, & the Marshal S. Audre, wherof we haue spoken here before.

The chief ende of all these counselles was, to make themselues wel assured of the towne of Paris, and to driue the Prince of Cōdee out of the same, as he which muche hindered their enterprise: To go and sease
theimselues of the personnes of the kinge and the Quéene, and after to bringe theym into the saide towne, wherby hauinge thone and thother at their cōmaundement, they might there the better bring to passe therecution of their enterprise. And forasmuch as the presence of the sayde Lorde the Prince, did greatly offend the Duke of Guise, not willinge to go out of the towne so longe as the Prince shoulde be there, notwythstandyng that in comming to Paris he caused it to bee bruited that he would not lye there but one nyght, he deuised to cause a report to goo, that the said Prince was at Parys accompanied with a greate number of gentelmen, & that the towne fearinge to be sacked had praied him to tary for the defence of it. Which the Prince vnderstandynge, to take away all occasion of malicious suspicion falslye deuised, offered incontinently to the Cardinall of Burbon deputed as then gouernoure of the town of Paris, yt he was readye to go forth of one of the gates, when ye D. of Guise shuld go out at an other. The Marshal Montmorency ye right
gouernoure of the towne then beynge dyscharged, at the instigacyon of the prouost of Marchauntes, as one whom he thought to wise & considerate for to endure his factions, and suborned sedicions.

But the Duke of Guise hauynge refused to accept this office, the said Lord Prince, being aduertised that the Quene desired that they should depart of thone syde and that her, & yt for this cause, the king of Nauarre was come to Paris, was so ready & so willing tobey this cōmaundement, that albeit he had bene sick in hys bed twoo dayes together, he staid not for al that readily to withdraw himself with all his company, drawing streight home to his house of La Feate, with mind to sende away al his company, if the Duke of Guise had done the like. But the Duke of Guise hauinge that he required went in such furniture of armure as he was, to mete with oure yong kinge, and the Quene his mother at Fontainbleau, where seinge her self, on al sides, compassed about to armes and force against her wil, & expresse cōmaundement, she found herself in great feare.

In this meane season the Prouost of marchauntes, desirous too make the towne of Paris well assured to the deuotion of the house of Guyse, leued immediatly the number of .xv hundreth men for the garde therof, withoute any assēble of the townsmen, or determination of thē, thervpon first made. Wheras before he had (as farrefoorth as he could) refused to receyue onely three hundreth men, appointed by the Kyng to the sayde Marshall Montmorency, beinge gouernour. And the same refusall made, after many assembles of the towne called to this ende, alledginge as then that it was againste the priuileges and franchises of the same, not hauinge bene accustomed to haue any other garde thenne the garde of the burgeses, and with the number of fiftene hundreth menne, thus established by him, he gaue fre libertie too the citiezens to furnishe theym selfe, and vse those weapons whiche had ben restored vnto them, whiche thing was executed wt such and insolency by the vulgare people, as it semed too bee a frontiere towne in the time of hostilita, seing
that there was nothinge sene nor heard of all sides, but weapons and artillary together with many robberies and outrages, specially done vpon them, whiche were of the religion (whiche they call new) goinge or cominge frome thassemblies, too serue God and to heare his woorde, in such sort as the Marshal de Leemes, willinge one daye to stay such force, was there him selfe in greate hasard of his person, and coulde not so prouide, but that ther were forth within his presence fyue or six murders committed, his own folkes iniured, without that any iustice hath therof ben done, no more thē was of other violēces perpetrated through ye fury of the people. For the duke of Guise and the Cōstable them selfs, who came after to Paris, sente for the Prouost of the sayde lorde Marshal, and afterward for the Lieutenant crimines of the same town, to whome (with sore threatnings, and castinge of them in feare) they gaue very expresse commaundement, too suppresse thinformatiōs of the cause whiche they hadde before them, and
to set those at libertye, whome they had enprisonned.

It happened that the sayde lorde prince hauing ben at his house, toke his waye for to returne to the court as he had promised to doe immediately after the feast of Easter, whiche the house of Guise hauinge vnderstoode, sende woorde foorth with to the Prouost of the marchauntes, to stande vppon his garde, and specially to let, that the sayde Prince shoulde not entre into the towne. Wherein suche diligence was vsed by the sayde Prouost, that immediatlye, and without further assemble of the towne (as he is wont to do) he signified to all the quartermaisters of the towne, to goe & warne all the houses of the same, that euery man shoulde be in a readines, and afterwardes hauing caused all the barre chaynes of the towne to be drawen (whiche hathe not bene accustomed nor sene too bee done, but in tyme of hostilitie and greate daunger, and whenne the ennemye approcheth) hee armeth hym selfe: and
& accompanied with all the archers and harquebousiers, and many marchauntes of the towne of Paris, he made his muster in the same: and as the said lorde Prince passed by, nere Paris, with those whiche accompanied him, going to lodge that night at sainct Cloud, and thinkinge nothinge lesse then to desire too entre into the sayd towne, the Prouost of 〈◊〉 marchaunts caused ordinaunce to be continually shot of, in such sorte as there is no remembraunce, that there hath suche a stirre ben sene in the saide towne these hundreth yeares & more, what daunger of warre soeuer hath happened in this realm.

Assone as the saide house of Guise vnderstoode, that the saide lorde the Prince drew streight towardes the court, well considering that his presence in that place should not be for their furtheraunce, and would lette them to bringe awaye the king and the Queene to the towne of Paris, to haue thone and thother in theyr power, accordinge too their first deuise: euen sodenly abusing the king of Nauarres authorite, whom they had & yet haue altogether on theyr
side, did so much as he came streight to tell the Queene, that she must departe from Fontainebleau, for the suertie of the Kinges person, layng maliciously too the Princes charge that he woulde come to sease of the Kinges person. Whiche the Quene streighte hereuppon woulde haue dissuaded vnto the king of Nauarre declaringe vnto him that it was no meanes credible, beinge greatelye amased with this matter: The king also sayinge that he woulde not go from Fontainbleau. But the sayde kynge of Nauarre, thrust forwarde by the saide house of Guyse, whoe sawe that otherwise their purpose was brooken, spake againe too the sayde Ladye, sayinge that she muste nedes departe, and that hee went to take the Kynge, and that she should folowe after if she wold. Approchinge then in this sort to the persone of the Kyng, who was wepinge with the Quene his mother. they hastened him forward so well, as wc in a little whyle, they brought hym into the towne of Melun, wher they lodged him within the Castle, in the whiche no kinge had lodged
these hūdreth years, nor any others, but suche as haue ben wont too bee sent thither prisoners.

My lord the prince vnderstanding this news, perceiuing that the meaninge of the saide lorde of Guise, was plainely ynough, declared too the woorlde (though before manye doubted thereof) wayinge that he was a prince of the bloud, and that by the lawe of nature it apertayned vnto him to defende the kyngs subiectes, and namely to resist suche as woulde oppresse theym by force and violēce: thought best for his sauety to return him self to Orleans, and from thence to geue all the kynges subiects to vnderstand his meaning & desire, to preuent the Imminent daunger, which hanged ouer theym all, to thintent they wold assist him to restore the person of the king, the Queene, & the duke of Orleans too liberty, and to maintaine the kings edicts in their force and strength.

The house of Guise this meane tyme, perceiuinge the saide Prince to be retired from them, but not too suche a place, as they woulde haue wished, too haue better inioyed his company, beganne more ouertly to
execute their enterprise, causing the kynge of Nauarre to tel the Quene that she must go to Paris, albeit the Kinge spake of nothing elles but of his return to Fontainebleau, & cessed not to wepe with the queene his mother, seinge euidently their captiuite, & specially the Queene whoe sawe that happen, which was declared vnto her, too the greate grief of his obedient subiects and seruaūts. And so muche was done by the help of the Prouost of merchaunts, who eftsones persisted to sende woorde, that the presence of the kynge was nedeful at Paris, so as being resolued in the morninge to goe to Fontainebleau, after dynner immediately the purpose was altered to goe to Paris.

The Constable hauing knowledge of thys resolution, toke vpō him to be one of the first at Paris, to begin to execute their enterprisemēt to be done, throughoute al the townes of this realme, as sithēs theffects whiche haue folowed, haue geuē mē tūderstande, & that with the greatest terror and strikinge of a feare in to men that he coulde in suche sorte, as departing from Melun at one of the
clocke at after noone, accompanied with two hundreth horses or more, al furnished with ii. or. iii. pistolets, entred into the sayde towne aboute eight of the clocke at night, and the next morninge very early he wente without any charge or commission to apprehēde monsieur de Ruze, an aduocate in the court of parlamēt, who asking him by what authorite, he maide him prysoner, & for what cause, he had no aunswer but these woordes: Content your selfe, that I am Constable: for in dede he doeth pretende, that withoute other commission or commaundemēt, he hath power to commaunde in thabsence of the kynge, and the kynge of Nauarre, whatsoeuer he should thinke good, as he spake aloude too all the worlde: doinge all thinges in suche rage, as is incredible to many.

The sayde Ruze, hauinge bene thus taken and sent prysoner to the Bastille, within a very straict prysone, for what cause no man as yet knoweth (oneles it be for that he is one of them, whiche did mooste frequent and fauour openly the reformed religiō) he went forth with one
of the Towne to a house named the Temple of Ierusalem, nere S. Iames gate (in which place the assembly and preaching was made) where he caused to be plucked downe, and throwne to thearth ye Pulpit wherin they preached, and certain seates and stooles whiche were there, and the same heaped altogether, caused it to be set on fire, beinge assisted wyth a verye greate number of the Vulgar people, which blessed hym, and praised him very highly, to see him do so vertuous, and so worthy a dede, for a Constable of Fraūce, the said Constable saiyng openlye, that there must be no more such assēblies within this Realm, & that the preachers must nedes retire them selues thence, and that there shoulde be an Edict published to that ende. From thens he went to doe asmuche after diner, in an other howse when also thassēblies were made named Popincourt, which is withoute S. Anthonyes gate: and there waited vppon, yea more then before, by the vulgar sorte, after he had caused the Pulpyt to be throwne downe, and
the seates and it to be laid together he did the lyke of that he did, at the other house, so as the people seynge thēselfs so much made of by a Constable of Fraunce, euen as though • he had bene in a maner their felow; they were so wel kindled, as not satisfied to haue set on fire the Pulpits and seates, they tooke boldnes forthwith (the said Constable being present and consentinge) to sette on fire the house which was great and wide, so as now it is razed to the verye grounde.

And this vulgar people foolish and mad by meanes of the familiaritys shewed theym by the Constable, not yet satisfied, through the general libertye giuen to all menne to weare weapons at the becke and commaūdement of the prouost of Merchauntes: that .iiii. or .v. dais together ther was nothing hard and spoken of but murthers, robberies, pillages, and open iniuries vsed by the people vpō ye next vnto thē, of what quality soeuer they were, if they had bene in neuer so litel suspicyon of religiō, & there was not so honest a man, that in passing by the streates (if he were
in the least suspicion that coulde be trew or false for the same religion) yt was not iniured & outraged, euery man hauing full liberty to carye pistolettes in the streates, insomuch as of all sides there was nothynge heard but continual noise of shot.

Sone after the comminge of the Constable, the king and the Quene were brought to Boys de Vincennes, and euen after the next morow the said house of Guise, because that place was not stronge ynoughe for their pourpose, caused the kynge to hasten his entry, because they wold lodge him in the castle of the Louure as the place whyche they tooke to be mooste safe for theym. Suche an entree beynge made after a • aci •
on not accustomed & with the diminishing of the kings greatnes, euen amonges straunge nacions; whiche was done, for that they supposed hereby to hide the knowledge of the kinges fowle captiuity, wherin thei do miserablye retaine hys maiestye: And to keepe hym in a place more assured for their deuocion, fourthwyth hereuppon they beganne to
deuise to make open warre vpon the said Lord Prince, & meaning to take counsail therein together, the Constable said to the L. Chaūcelor, who was there presente in the kynges chamber, that this busynes belonged not but to suche as be exercised u • armes, to whom the sayde Lorde Chauncelor said, that albeit he and those of his coore were not skilled in handlynge of weapons, yet for all that they coulde tell well inoughe, when they are to be vsed, and not to be vsed, neuertheles forasmuche as then (as also it is presently) all was done with force, and open violence, he was kept from theim alofe, as he hath bene alwayes sythens, and to be the more assured of themselues in all thinges, namely to haue ye kings counsail at their commaundement, thei made therof by their own authority, those of whō thei thought they might make sore accoumpt as le seigneur de Boily maister of the horse, the Court villars, being kinsemen, and allyed with the saide Constable, le seigneur de Sen • a • , a verye affectionate seruaunte to the said house of Guise and the Constable, le seigneur Descars,
and the Bishop of Auxerre houshold seruauntes to the king of Nauarre, and whose meanes the sayd house of Guise do vse, specially to go aboute at their secret practises, and put out those whom they sawe prefar • e the common wealth, before their: owne priuate passion.

But to retourne to their counsels and executyons of the same, the house of Guise hauing vnderstanded the protestacyon and declaratyon made on the said L. the Princes behalfe, and sent to the king, the effect whereof was, that he not sturred with anye partyculer affection, but rather with the duty and onely loue whiche he particularlye bare to the crown, vnder the gouernment of the Queene, he had bene constrayned to enter into armes, to restore the persone of the kinge and the Quene, to their ful libertye, and to maintaine thobseruacion of the kings maiesties Edictes and ordenances, and namely the last touchinge the cause of religion, offeringe to retourne to his house, if the D. of Guise woulde doe the like.

Thei hauing then perceiued this declaration, and seing there were two points which they must finely cloke and couer, that is to wit, the kinges captiuity, and the countermandinge of the diet of Ianuary they procured in all haste thexpedicion of a letter theight of Aprill last paste, whereby the king declared, that the bru • t of his captiuitye is a false and • an vntrue sklaunder, inuented by the said lord the Prince therby to excuse him self of his doynges, declarynge that the Quene and he were in such lybertye as they haue euer bene, & as they coulde wyshe, and that he and the saide Ladye came of their owne mindes, into the saide towne of Paris to prouide for and to remedy the troubles happened.

And the Court of Parlament was sent vnto, to reade and publysh the said letters, which was done so readilye or rather all hedlonge, and againste all custome, that (beynge brought to ye Chamber of plees, and whiles that men were playdinge of matters, they were incontynentlye delyuered to the kynges mynysters and the publication therof required
at their handes) euen in one instant, it was ordered that they shoulde be redde, published, and inregistred▪ Streight after, callinge to remembraunce vpon a sodayne a more subtyll wile and craft, in causing other letters of the xii. day folowing to be couched, whereby it is declared that the said lorde Prince, vnder a faulse and counterfait colour of religion, was seased in hys persone, by some sedicious persones, which kept him in their handes.

And to mete with thother, and second point purported by the declaratyon made by the sayde Lorde Prince, touching the matter of relygion, they cause other letters of the xi. of the same moneth to be dispatched, wherby the kinge geueth tunderstande, that he is informed, that diuerse haue retired theim selues to Orleauns (assembled in great numbers) and to other places, vnder color of a feare whiche they saye they haue, that their consciences shalbe searched, and that they shalbe staide from the vsynge of Thedyctes and ordenances made by him, namely in ye last moneth of Ianuary, touching
the matter of religion, and to vexe and trouble theym for the opinion whyche they holde. He declareth by the same, that to take away all feare and doubte, he hath not ment to call the sayde Edyct to question, neyther that anye shuld be touchinge the cause of religion molested, except the Towne of Paris, Faulxbourges, and Baylywike of the same, wherin the sayd kynge declareth, that he will not haue anye publike or priuate assēblies made, nor anye adminystration of Sacramentes in other sorte, then as hath beene receyued and obserued in the Church of Roome. Which letters beinge presented in the saide Court by the saide Duke of Guise and the Constable, albeit they were altogether contrary to Thedict of Ianuarye, whiche is generall for all the townes, yet are they redde, publysshed, and enrolled, wherunto the said Court added, that the said readynge and publication made by the same, is, in respect of the present necessytye of the tyme, and as it were only by waye of a prouision, & vntil suche time as it be otherwise prouided
which discouereth sufficiently yt the meaning of the said Court, and the D. of Guise is all one, that is, to make frustrate the last Edict of Ianuary, in kepinge too their vse the chiefe towne, like as the saide D. of Guise did at that time euedently declare in the sayde Court: So as yet further, the matter was made more apparaūt by other letters depeched at the same tyme: By the which the kynge declareth, that he meaneth not that the saide Edict take place, but in the townes, where the preachers were already established, and not in the rest. Whiche were in this sort sent foorth, partly too serue for an occasion, to make the cruell and horrible slaughter, whiche folowed soone after in the towne of Sens, where against all huminite a great number of people were killed, besides great robberies and sackinge of houses, whiche continued two dais together, and not without great suspiciō, against the cardinal of Guise, archebishop there, and of his ministers and seruaunts. Which is the sūme of all that I haue ben able too gather of yt whiche hath happened
hitherto, couering the present trouble and controuersie, beinge in thys realme, and for whiche euery man in thesame is in armes.

It resteth now to gyue tunderstād by degrees all the reasons wherewt thone side & thother may help them selfs, to cause al men more perfectly knowe whiche of the twoo is better grounded, & may be said to haue entred into armes with best righte of their side. We haue now sene howe the house of Guise, ye cōstable & Marshal s. Andre, withdrew them selfes frō the Courte one after another, & the smal regard they haue had to ye Quene, sithens they haue felt them self backt with the king of Nauarre & how their best & chief pretext hath alwayes ben, that they do arme thē selfs to maintayne the Catholique religion. Takinge occasion to finde faulte with the gouermente of the realme: charginge the Quene much for her owne greate lenite and softnes, the Kynges counsayl, for winkinge at thinges, and the magistrates for their negligence, and aboue all thinges complayning of the last
Edict of Ianuary. We haue also sene the beginning, procedinge, and ende of their ētreprice, alwaies guided by violence and strong hand, by murthers and shedding of bloude, & by disobeinge the Queenes expresse cōmaundements: & next their counsail deuided frō the king. The sollicitations, stirres, & tumultes raised in the towne of Paris, by suche as were suborned, & by making muche of the people, seruing much to theyr purpose. And lastly the seasinge of the kyng and Quenes persons, the pressinge of the Kynges counsaill & to his officers of iustice, hauing eue violently extorted, and in dede verified one lettre in an others necke, cōtrary to custome and the Edicts.
On the prince of Condee his side, we see too the contrary, hys goinge frome the Courte with the Queenes fauoure, and with promisse too retourne thyther foorthwyth.

We see hys abode at Parys too haue bene quiet, and requisite to staye the styrres, which were there towards. And next his ready obeing of the Quenes commaundementes,
although it had ben more fette for the D. of Guise first to haue obeyed the same. The outrage and iniurie done to the sayde lorde by the Prouost of the marchaunts, as if it had ben to an enemy of the croune, born neuerthelesse paciently by the sayde prince. His returninge to Orleans for the sauety of his persone, and of his, after that the Kinge & Quenes captiuitie, was verye openlye discouered. And lastely the declaration of the cause that moued him too entre into armes, sente by hym too the kynge, with offer to retire him selfe, and to lay doune his force, so as the house of Guise would doe the like, the kinges Edicts remayninge in their force.
So as there is none, that seeth not clearly on the one part all obediēce to the Queene, and on thother side disobedience towardes the same.

That thone side tooke weapon in hande to offende, and thother to defende. The violence of thone, and the withstanding therof in thother. Thone meaning to subuert ye kings law by force, & of his own auctorite. Thother as a prince of the bloude,
& one of the Protectors of the lawes of Fraunce, mynded to maintaine the same: and consequently the one continuinge hys duety, and thother setled in the doing of wronge. For what greate matter is it, that the house of Guise can pretend, to touch then, by retiring of themselfs, and to lay doune their force, seinge that my lorde the Prince is contended so to do? What reason can they alledg for them selfs, to minde of thē selfs, to disanull that which the Estates haue so earnestly required, and the Kinge by suche departe of counsaill hath graunted? If they say, thei wil defend the Churche of Rome, whoe is it that hindereth them to do it?

Doeth any man se the Bishops and Curates, driuen frome their Churches, doeth any see them staide from preachinge, and too doe that whiche good and faithfull ministers ought to do? Or elles is it not, than they beare malice to them of the religion (whiche they call newe) to see them do so well, as to be driuē out of the townes, as men infected with lepre or pestilence, setfoorthe to the raine and wynde, and in the contempte of
euery man? Are there so many Christen people, which abide the Iewes in their townes, & namely the Popes holines, doth suffer them in hys chief town, and els where: and shall not those whiche confesse the name of Iesu Christe, as he in whom they beleue is onely their saluation, doe beleue & suffer for his Gospell sake, finde a place in Fraunce too retire them selfes to?

Yea, but forsoth (say they) Is this a dede of a good religiō, to take possession of the kinges townes & places, too entre into armes, withoute his leaue and licence, and too kepe backe the money groynge of his reuenue? I woulde willingly aske the question, before I aūswer them, Is it a token of good religion, too possesse them selfs of the Kyng & Quenes persones, and of the chief town of hys Realme, of all hys force, aucthoritie, and substaunce, too employe the same, to the thinfringing of hys Edicts, too oppresse his subiectes, and subuert hys estate, and too thys ende too vse the ayde of straungers, seing the subiectes will not cōsent to so manifest a tyranny?
See then I prai you, how quick witted we are in other mens cases, and blinded in oure owne. Nowe I saye then to aunswer theym, that is falleth for my lorde the Prince, as a Prince of the bloude, a counsailor borne, and one of the Protectors of the croune, euen to whome by lawe of nature appertayneth the defence of the subiectes, when some woulde by violence oppresse them, to resiste therto by dynt of swearde, whiche God too this ende hath putte in hys handes, and consequently to maintaine the lawes and Edictes of the Realme. And touchinge the townes & places, wherof they complaine, yt the sayde lord Prince is s • ased: hath the kinge found him selfe any worse serued & obeyed, then he hathe bene heretofore, and hathe there ben any alteration perceiued, but onely that they do arme them selfes, not myndinge to submitte them selfes to the violente oppression of the house of Guise, And touchynge the money deteyned, I desire too knowe, wherein a manne shoulde blayme hym, whoe hathe taken a knyfe oute of a madde mannes handes,
If then my lorde the Prince, mente to staye that the house of Guise doe not abuse the Kinges treasure, too cause straungers too entre into hys realme, and oppresse his subiectes, wherein is he to be reproued?

But to dilate yet somwhat further, and by degrees their reasons, not willinge to omit any one of theym, if it were possible, I woulde willingly aske them, by what meanes it is, that they mynde to defende the Romish religion; for the which they declare themselfes so well minded? It is by force, saye they, in driuinge awai the ministers out of ye realme, in takinge awaie thassemblies, and puttinge to death the chiefest of the contrary religion; accordinge to the example of the sedition of Xantonge and of Bourdeaux, withoute anye searchinge of mens consciences, soo that they conteyne them selfs within their houses, and make no shewe thereof abrode. I can not ynoughe meruail of suche a counsail, and deuise, altogether contrarye, too that whiche they thē selfs, euen the very house of Guise it self, I saie (hauing at that time in their handes, in the tyme
of the last king Fraunces the hoole gouernment of the Realme) caused to be published by letters and Edictes: and at such time as the number of theym whom they persecute, and persecuted before was a great deale fewer, and muche more easye to oppresse by force then they be nowe.

For they were of opinion, that all rigor should ceasse, (as a thinge vnfit for the age of a yonge kinge, and vnsemely, wherupon his comyng to the croune of Fraūce, should be noted to hys posteritye to haue bene bloudye) & that troubles and diuisions should be ended, by conuocations of the cleargie of the Realme, & thither to call and admitte al sortes of people that woulde come to propone any thinges for the matter of religion, which purpose hauing ben broken by the death of the late laste kinge was executed in thys kynges reigne, in continuyng of that which by theimselues was thought good, and sythens confirmed by thaduyse of all the Prynces of the bloude, Cardinalles and others of the priuy counsayl assembled in the Courte of Parliament.

The house of Guise they hauyng sene that this way could do no good (and some know wherfore) and hauing theym selues perceiued made and so often repeted by thestates, to thend to haue Temples, and being knowen, that the Quene left nothing vndone to finde some good remedye, was in thende driuen to the remedy of thedict made in Ianuary last, by the aduise of the moste hable and sufficient men of this Realme, as the best and mooste commodious meanes, it is a marueilous matter to see that they are neuertheles eftsones come to set forwarde the meanes of force, and in dede they haue taken the same in hand: as thoughe thei had already forgottē what good it did them, when they wente from Paris to Orleans, enuironned with menne of warre, euen like as if they had bene in thenemies countrye and vnder color of a conspiracy made againste the late last kinge, who by reason of his youth and good nature had neuer done any manne dyspleasure.

And if it so be that thexamples of
the tyme paste, and speciallye of the Arrians, Nouatins, and Macedoniens (to whom for the selfe same reasons Temples were geuen, sometimes without and somtimes within the townes) cannot serue at al to moue vs, to tollerate the lyke, that yet at the least they whome we haue sene before our eyes, may haue this power giuen them, to make vs wiser for the time to come? haue we not sene in Almaine as muche troubled for the same matter of religion and more then we be? and coulde one wyshe more carefullnesse, wisedome, and force then was in Themperour Charles the fyfth, worthy indede to be placed amongst the greatest, & yet there is none of vs who hath not seene before his eyes, that all that coulde doe no good to appease the troubles for relygyon, till that he was at laste contented to graunte an Interim, synce the whyche the Countrey of Almayne was neuer seene in greater peace and quietnes hath the waye of force & rigor serued to any great purpose
in the realme of Englande? and too proceade to the realme of Scotland in what daunger haue we seene it, some thinking by the self same house of Guise reigning then in Fraunce, to do those thinges then which presentlye they haue eftsones begonne here: What reason is it then to say, that it is by force yt we must mainetain the Catholike relygion, in driuing away the Mynisters (say they) oute of the Realme, as if that there were not a millyon euen amonges them that heare them (if a man may thus call them sufficient) to execute thoffice and charge of a minister.

But their ignoraunce and rashnes doeth yet declare it selfe forther by thother point which they set forthe, making comparison of a trouble in religion with a matter of a popular sedicion. In the which they that rebel and be armed against the Prince at the very time that they are moste sedicious, they acknoweledge their fault in their conscience. And those which do stirre for the matter of religion, they are so farre of from thoughte of euill doynge, that they
woulde for nothing hurt any man, nor therby to contrary the duetye of good and faithfull subiectes toward their kinge and liege lorde: So as it appereth that this is a foolyshe and vnaduised opinyon, to thynke that when the heades be dispatched, that it should be easy to brynge thothers back again, which oftentymes shew them as steadfast & constant, & their heades and conductour. And yet is it lesse wyt and reason, to saye that whiche they adde further, as it were wyth great prudence intermingled with lenitye, that is that they wyll not search mens conscyences so that euery one wil kepe himself at home. For besides that it is impossible to do it, as they do better vnderstād it, then thothers know it: there should not be a better meane to take away al discipline, and reuerence of God from amongst menne, and in thende to aboundaunce them to all libertye of vyce, beinge necessarye that euery mans relygyon be ordered and witnessed publiquely.

Yea but (saye they) oure realme canne not indure twoo religions. We see the contrarye in the moste
parte of Europe, thys beynge no perticuler disease of this Realme. Wherefore then maye not they well suffer the like? There is not one of eyther of the religions, but woulde wyshe there were but one of them.

But seinge it is thus happened, yet must the best meanes be deuised and we become wise at the leaste by thexample of others, yea but (saye they agayne) yf that take place, the new religion will dailye encrease, & in thend wil come to destroy ours. See here a good beginnynge of the distrust they haue of the goodnes of their religiō: For if it be of God, we muste not doubte, but it wyll surmount thother, and that it shal continue.

But that whyche causeth them to saye so, is thexample they haue before their eies, of the force of this religion (which they call new) whiche thoughe it be but poore, abiecte and neglected of all menne, hath not let notwithstandinge in a fewe yeares, to embrace almoste al Europe, and to ouercome and haue the vpperhande of armure, for • e, and violence
of Emperours, and Kynges, the pompe, riches, pride, & the height of Popes, Cardynalles, and al their followers. I desire to knowe for thys pourpose, if the Iuishe religion thoughe it haue beene suffered in Chrystendome more then a thousand yeares, hathe therfore destroyed and hyndered the Christian religion.

Thus the whole beinge wel discoursed, and ripely waied, there is great apparance, that it is not zeale of conscience, whiche pusheth theym forwarde, who declare theym selfe so well affected to the Romyshe relygyon, hauynge speciallye thys marke to shoote at before their eyes, to possesse themselues of the gouernemente of the Realme, and if they coulde of the Crowne it selfe and all vnder the visour and cloke of the Kynge of Nauarre, by vsynge hym to serue their tourne, afterwards to oppresse hym, and enter into hys place, and (to comme to thys ende) they ayde theym selues wyth a cloke of religion,
meaninge too maintaine the Popes aucthoritie, whiche serueth their tournes so well vnder the colour therof, and nothinge lesse, then to haue an eye too the peace of consciences, and quiet of the subiectes: In suche sort, as he that would saye at one woorde, that this is the Popes warre, shoulde not perhaps bee very farre from the truthe.

This hauinge ben alwayes the forme and maner of his holines, procedinge in mater of religion, and of al his ministres suborned by him to raise vp warres, thereby to constraine men by force, to raūge them selfs to his church, like as contrariwise, the waye of the Gospell hathe ben, to bringe men of their own accorde, through preaching the woord of God vnto them.

And we shall see in thende, which of the two wayes shalbe founde the best. They shal perceiue, how much they, with whome they haue to do, are bounde, ioyned, & vnited together, and stedfaste and constante in their opinion. How many thousand amonges theym, doe make no difficultie
to lose their goods, and rather to dye then to chaunge, and refuse the doctrine, whiche they haue receiued. And they shall agayne knowe, that to gayn them by force, they must cause them all to dye, for that otherwise, he that shall remain or liue, with the asshes of them that shall dye, wil cause others to be raised. Iudge you whether it be not a fayre and goodly entreprice, to haue called in straungers, vtterly too extinguishe the floure of Fraunce, & to set the realm in a praye. O mōstruous vnfaithfulnes, worthy to be assailed by all men, as a wyld beast. To call (I saye) straungers to settle oure controuersies, & to gyue vntoo them the places of thē, which shal be ouercomen, and to kepe him vnderfoote, to whome there shal remaine but the name of a victor.

And nowe too make an ende, it nedeth not (as I take it) too excuse my lord the Prince of that, that his aduersaries woulde maliciouslye impute vnto him, iudging his meaninge, accordinge too their owne. Sayinge: that this is not (as it is
not in dede for their parte) the zeale of religion that moued hym. And that hys griefe is in an other place, procedinge of some affection of hatred, reuenge or ambition. If the sayde lorde the Prince hadde not already gyuen me sufficientlye tunderstande, that he is nothinge lesse then vindicatif, and that accordinge to the profession, whiche he maketh of the Gospel, he hath remitted all reuenge to God, he woulde not denye but that the house of Guyse hath geuen hym sufficient occasion, to enter into this desire of reuenge. And as touching the matter of ambition, they them selfes knowe better howe he hath liued heretofore, and howe hee is increased in substaunce, and that if he were altogether distempered (as they be) with this thursting after goods, aucthoritie, and greatnes, that it is longe of none, but of hym selfe that thesame is not quenched.

And (to make an ende) you haue here the discours by degrees, of the cōtrouersy happened in this realme and the causes and reasons, that
maye be alledged of thone side and thother, too haue moued eyther of the partyes, too haue entred into armes. Nowe resteth it in euery subiectes choyse, or anye other, hauing desire to stirre, to the partakyng with thone or thother, too iudge sincerelye, and without passion, to whiche of the twoo parties hee shall do best to ioyn hym selfe.
